customer_name: Kennedy Meadows Wild Canine Conservation Inc.
site_name: Kennedy Meadows Wild Canine Conservation Inc

citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
The facility has been using gentamicin ophthalmic drops with an expiration date of October 2023 to medicate the right eye
of one of their adult male wolves. Expired medications may be ineffective and are more likely to have been contaminated
and could potentially worsen the medical condition being treated. Medicines used to prevent or treat disease must be
properly stored, labeled, and not expired in order for them to appropriately and effectively prevent, control, and/or treat
diseases.

citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
An adult male wolf had a pink, approximately 0.3cm soft tissue mass, adjacent to the lateral canthus of the right eye. The
facility reported the condition as a chronic issue that periodically gets aggravated, requiring treatment. The facility has
been treating the eye with antibiotic ophthalmic drops for several days. In addition, an adult female wolf was observed to
be mildly lame in one of her back legs, noted only during a few short sprints in the enclosure. The attending veterinarian
had not been informed about either wolves’ conditions. All animals should be observed on a daily basis, with any
problems conveyed to the attending veterinarian in a timely manner. Failure to consult with a veterinarian and provide
appropriate diagnostics and treatment can result in a poor outcome for animals. A mechanism of direct and frequent
communication is required so that timely and accurate information on problems of animal health, behavior, and well-being
is conveyed to the attending veterinarian.
This is a 2nd Re-License Inspection for a Class “C” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the
applicant.
All items must be in compliance within 1 more inspection(s) or by 3 Jan 2026 or the applicant will forfeit the license fee
and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection.
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.
Additional Inspectors:
William Campbell, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

narrative:
2.40(b)(2) 
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
The facility has been using gentamicin ophthalmic drops with an expiration date of October 2023 to medicate the right eye 
of one of their adult male wolves. Expired medications may be ineffective and are more likely to have been contaminated 
and could potentially worsen the medical condition being treated. Medicines used to prevent or treat disease must be 
properly stored, labeled, and not expired in order for them to appropriately and effectively prevent, control, and/or treat 
diseases. 
2.40(b)(3) 
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
An adult male wolf had a pink, approximately 0.3cm soft tissue mass, adjacent to the lateral canthus of the right eye. The 
facility reported the condition as a chronic issue that periodically gets aggravated, requiring treatment. The facility has 
been treating the eye with antibiotic ophthalmic drops for several days. In addition, an adult female wolf was observed to 
be mildly lame in one of her back legs, noted only during a few short sprints in the enclosure. The attending veterinarian 
had not been informed about either wolves’ conditions. All animals should be observed on a daily basis, with any 
problems conveyed to the attending veterinarian in a timely manner. Failure to consult with a veterinarian and provide 
appropriate diagnostics and treatment can result in a poor outcome for animals. A mechanism of direct and frequent 
communication is required so that timely and accurate information on problems of animal health, behavior, and well-being 
is conveyed to the attending veterinarian. 
 
This is a 2nd Re-License Inspection for a Class “C” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the 
applicant. 
 
All items must be in compliance within 1 more inspection(s) or by 3 Jan 2026 or the applicant will forfeit the license fee 
and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection. 
 
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.

Additional Inspectors: 
William Campbell, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n
